repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.abstract: The collection includes personal and professional correspondence, literary manuscripts by American author Tillie Olsen and others, material on the Longshoremen's Strike and the Socialist Party from during the mid-1930s, teaching material and student work, clippings, pamphlets, book reviews, awards, etc. Accessions from 2009 including photographs have also been processed.
did.physloc: Special Collections and University Archives materials are stored offsite and must be paged 36-48 hours in advance. For more information on paging collections, see the department's website: http://library.stanford.edu/spc.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Tillie Olsen was born in Nebraska in 1913 and has lived in San Francisco for most of her life. Her education was cut short by the Depression: she wrote and published when young, but the necessity of raising and supporting four children and full-time work prevented her from writing for twenty years. She was in her mid-forties before she began again. Tell Me A Riddle was originally published in 1962, and its title novella received the O. Henry Award as the best American story of 1961. In 1974, forty years after part of its chapter appeared in an early Partisan Review, her 'lost' novel, Yonnondio: From the Thirties, was published. Tillie Olsen has taught at Amherst College, Stanford University, was Writer-in-Residence at Massachustts Institute of Technology, Distinguished Visiting Professor at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, and a Fellow of the Radcliffe Institute. She has received both a Ford Foundation and National Endowment for the Arts grants, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and an Award for Distinguished Contribution to American Literature from the American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Her first work of non-fiction, Silences, was published in 1979.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Tillie Olsen Papers. M0667. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I is comprised of her manuscripts and related material. This includes the original drafts from Tell Me a Riddle, Yonnondio: From the Thirties, Silences, Requa, and other miscellaneous publications in both magazines and newspapers. Also included are galleys, typescripts, corrections to texts, adaptations, translations, reviews and various stage production scripts. [The listing often makes reference to the word "makings" which was Tillie Olsen's designation for her own notes and writings for the particular text.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of material from 1930-1950, and this series is divided into two distinct parts. Series IIa, the first part, contains Tillie Olsen's personal writings from this time period, which include partial stories, verse, journal entries, and newspaper articles. Reference is made in this series to Olsen's involvement with the Socialist Party and the Longshoreman's Strike during the mid 1930's. This series ends with all her bound journals and notebooks, the majority of which she wrote in high school. Series IIb, also from the time period 1930-1950, contains newsclippings, pamphlets, and bulletins which pertain to the Longshoreman's Strike and various other Strike issues. There is reference to Tillie Olsen's prison sentence in the mid-1930's and an FBI file kept on Tillie Olsen until 1944. Finally, there is a collection of manuscripts which includes poems and stories written by various individuals other than Tillie Olsen during the 1930's, some of which were written by Jeannette Gray.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series III, Correspondence, is divided into five distinct sections, with each section determined by the time period or content of the particular correspondence. All the correspondence is incoming except when noted in the listing as "outgoing."

Series IIIa is personal correspondence written during the time period 1930-1950. This series is of particular interest because of the correspondence with such individuals as Robert Gehn, Arel Creel, Jeannette Gray, Marion "Dippy" Duve, and Malcolm Cowley.

Series IIIb is personal correspondence from 1950-1990 arranged alphabetically by name. Included in this series are individuals such as Margaret Atwood, Kay Boyle, Rachel Blau DuPlessis, Dick Elman, Hanna Green, Ursula LeGuin, Lewis Mumford, Katherine Anne Porter, Adrienne Rich, May Sarton, Scott Turow, and Alice Walker.

Series IIIc is also personal correspondence but arranged chronologically from 1960-1989. Series IIId consists of reader's responses to Tillie Olsen's writings along with invitations to talks, seminars, and workshops. Finally, Series IIIe is correspondence to and from publishers and general requests, i.e. publishing rights, permission to dramatize works, letters of recommendation, biographical information, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV is entitled "Manuscripts by Others." These are short stories, poems, and articles primarly written by friends of Tillie Olsen which were sent to her for either personal viewing or critical appraisal. Included are poems by Adrienne Rich, Anne Sextant, Scott Turow and short stories by Sandy Boucher, Michele Cliff, and Susan Griffin.

Series 5. Articles and Papers regarding Tillie Olsen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series V consists of articles and papers regarding Tillie Olsen. These are published articles that have appeared in magazines and journals along with student papers that have been sent to Olsen for her evaluation. Also included in this series are clippings from magazines and newspapers reviewing her books, movie adaptations, and public appearances. Finally, to end Series V, there is a section of unrelated papers and articles that Tillie Olsen kept for her own personal records.

Series 6. Transcripts of interviews and talks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VI contains transcripts of various interviews and talks given by Tillie Olsen during the years 1963-1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VII consists of teaching material and student work during the time Tillie Olsen taught at Amherst, MIT, University of Massachusettes, and Stanford. Class notes, students papers, student journals, and correspondence with the sudents comprise the majority of this series. Also included are folders referring to the Radcliffe Institute, which contains newsletters, pamphlets, and other ephemera regarding the Bunting Institute Society of Fellows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VIII contains articles, pamphlets, and degrees that pertain to the awards and honors Tillie Olsen received for her efforts as a writer and activist, including "Tillie Olsen Day" in San Francisco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IX is made up entirely of pamphlets and announcements sent to Tillie Olsen regarding various book readings, book reviews, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series X is the Miscellaneous section, consisting of various ephemera such as financial and legal papers, fragments of notes, teaching guides, catalogues, various writings, photographs, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series XI, the final series, contains different published editions of Tell Me a Riddle, Silences, and Yonnondio: From the Thirties. A few copies are of foreign editions, and some editions have her corrections in the margins. Also within this series are audio cassettes of various readings and talks, including tapes of her reading Tell Me a Riddle and "The Strike."
